timeline.bodyText: PlanBuilder has Session as parameter so why not extract the session functions and support it in tests?
timeline.author: rongrong

timeline.bodyText: I'm not sure there's confusion though. These functions are also session-scoped. The only difference is whether they are builtin or user-defined. Unless you want to repurpose the class name I think it's fine to leave it as SessionFunctions.
timeline.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText: I think it is clearer to call it SessionInformationFunction because it is not a function defined in a session. The function definition is the same no matter what session, and it retrieves a specific property of a session.
replies.author: prithvip

replies.bodyText: Ya, but functions defined in a session will never end up in the source code. So there should be no confusion that these functions are not defined in the session?
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText: Ok, I've changed it back to SessionFunctions.
replies.author: prithvip

timeline.bodyText: You are by passing function resolution here, which is probably why you need to handle coercion separately. All function resolution should go through the same logic, which is wrapped in resolveFunctionInternal. Function namespaces are only providing candidates with getFunction(transactionID, functionName).
timeline.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText: Outdated

timeline.message: Add support for temp functions in SHOW FUNCTIONS/SHOW CREATE FUNCTION

timeline.bodyText: This might be masking ACL issues? Or is past that?
timeline.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: This is just a parsed representation of the SQL function (no analysis at this point), but when a query containing this function is submitted for execution, the ACLs will be checked at analysis time.
replies.author: prithvip

replies.bodyText: What would happen if I create foo, drop foo then create foo again? Why do we need to track removed functions rather than just removing them?
replies.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText:
CREATE FOO
client sends query and session state
server sends back diff to session state, adding function foo
client applies diff to client state
DROP FOO
client sends query and session state (which includes function foo)
server sends back diff to session state, dropping function foo
client applies diff to client state, foo is now gone
CREATE FOO
client sends query and session state (no function foo)
server sends back diff to session state, adding function foo
client applies diff to client state, foo is now present

The design of console is such that the server always sends back diffs to the client state rather than the full client state. For example, session properties and prepared statements also work this way.
replies.author: prithvip

timeline.bodyText: How about error cases? Also, can they overwrite an existing function temporarily? If so, we want a test case for that as well.
timeline.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: Overwriting an existing function is not allowed. These are the CLI side tests, there are more tests on the server-side.
replies.author: prithvip

timeline.bodyText: Also test CREATE OR REPLACE
timeline.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: We are not supporting REPLACE syntax yet
replies.author: prithvip

timeline.bodyText: Can we make it a single api to get all visible functions instead of adding the second param through out?
timeline.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: I did some refactoring and reduced the "blast radius" of adding this second param and reduced the size of this PR by about 50 files. There's no easier solution here, because most of the compilers are singletons, connectors can access the compilers, the connectors don't have session, they have connector session, and so it all has to get threaded through.
replies.author: prithvip

timeline.bodyText: isReplace check here?
timeline.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: Analyzer will check for REPLACE, and throw if it is used with TEMPORARY.
replies.author: prithvip

timeline.bodyText: Where is the error if the function doesn't exist?
timeline.author: kaikalur

replies.bodyText: QueryStateMachine will throw an exception if the function doesn't exist, in method "removeSessionFunction"
replies.author: prithvip

timeline.bodyText: Is it just a refactor? Or did you have more changes too? If it's just a simple refactor, may be move it out.
timeline.author: kaikalur

timeline.bodyText: I kinda prefer this to be function_name(type,type,type...). Looks more like a function signature.
timeline.author: rongrong

replies.bodyText: The toString() does look like that, so that is what you would see when debugging. This is purely to serialize/deserialize, so I wanted to go with the simplest foolproof solution.
replies.author: prithvip

replies.bodyText: We're using SqlFunctionId.getValue, which is essentially calling toString() when storing it into MySQL. We should consolidate the two. Actually, the logic shouldn't even be here since it is due to a restriction unrelated / unaware to open source. The caller code, which is not in open-source, should be responsible for encoding / decoding SqlFunctionId in this special way.
replies.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: Do you want me to replace all the instances of getId() with toJsonString()?
replies.author: prithvip

timeline.bodyText: The result of the SHOW CREATE foo should be a CREATE TEMPORARY FUNCTION statement. The result SQL by itself is not semantically valid, as it is attempting to create a permanent function foo without specifying catalog and schema.
timeline.author: caithagoras

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: prithvip
